q: Is nipple discharge usually a sign of something serious?
a: No, nipple discharge is not usually a sign of something serious. It is often normal for women to have nipple discharge from time to time. However, it's a good idea to get it checked by a doctor if it happens regularly or if it has certain characteristics.

q: What are the common causes of nipple discharge?
a: Nipple discharge can have many possible causes. Some common causes include breastfeeding or pregnancy, a blocked or enlarged milk duct, a small non-cancerous lump in the breast, a breast infection, or a side effect of certain medications.

q: When should someone see a GP regarding nipple discharge?
a: If someone experiences nipple discharge and it happens regularly, only comes from one breast, is bloodstained or smelly, occurs without any pressure on the breast, or they have other symptoms such as a lump, pain, redness, or swelling in the breast, it is important to see a GP for further evaluation.

q: What happens during a GP appointment for nipple discharge?
a: During a GP appointment for nipple discharge, the GP will look at and examine the breasts. They may then refer the patient to a hospital or breast clinic for further tests, which may include a breast examination, a mammogram or ultrasound, and a biopsy if necessary.

q: Is nipple discharge more common in men or women?
a: Nipple discharge is more commonly seen in women. However, if men experience nipple discharge, it is considered abnormal and should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.

q: What does the color of nipple discharge indicate?
a: The color of nipple discharge is not a reliable indicator of whether it is serious or not. Normal discharge can be of various colors, and it is best to consult a healthcare professional for proper evaluation.

q: Is nipple discharge alone a sign of breast cancer?
a: Nipple discharge by itself is not usually a sign of breast cancer. However, it is still important to get it checked by a doctor, especially if there are other concerning symptoms present.

q: Are babies supposed to have nipple discharge after they are born?
a: Yes, it is not unusual for babies, both boys and girls, to have milky nipple discharge soon after they are born. This is a normal occurrence and should stop within a few weeks.

q: What tests are done at a breast clinic for nipple discharge?
a: At a breast clinic, various tests may be performed for nipple discharge, including a breast examination, a mammogram or ultrasound, and a biopsy if necessary. These tests help in further evaluation and determining the cause of the discharge.

q: Can a contraceptive pill cause nipple discharge?
a: Yes, a contraceptive pill can be one of the possible causes of nipple discharge. It is important to consult a healthcare professional for evaluation if nipple discharge is experienced while taking any medication.

q: What is nipple discharge?
a: Nipple discharge is the release of fluid from the nipples. It is usually not a sign of anything serious.

q: Is nipple discharge normal?
a: Yes, nipple discharge can be normal for women, especially during breastfeeding or pregnancy. It can also be normal for babies soon after they're born.

q: When should I see a GP for nipple discharge?
a: You should see a GP if nipple discharge happens regularly and is not a one-off, if it only comes from one breast, if it's bloodstained or smelly, if you're not breastfeeding and it leaks out without any pressure, if you're over 50, if you have other symptoms like a lump, pain, redness or swelling, or if you're a man.

q: What will happen at a GP appointment for nipple discharge?
a: The GP will look at and examine your breasts. They may refer you to a hospital or breast clinic for further tests, which can usually show that you do not have cancer.

q: What are the common causes of nipple discharge?
a: Common causes of nipple discharge include breastfeeding or pregnancy, a blocked or enlarged milk duct, a small non-cancerous lump in the breast, a breast infection, or a side effect of a medicine.

q: Is nipple discharge a sign of breast cancer?
a: Nipple discharge by itself is not usually a sign of breast cancer.

q: What are the possible tests at a breast clinic for nipple discharge?
a: At a breast clinic, you may have a breast examination, a breast X-ray (mammogram) or ultrasound, or a biopsy where a needle is inserted into your breast to remove some cells for testing.

q: When will I get the results of the tests done at a breast clinic?
a: You'll usually be told the results on the same day, although biopsy results can take longer and you should get them in a week or two.

q: Where can I get more information about nipple discharge?
a: You can get more information about nipple discharge from Breast Cancer Now.

q: What are some common breast conditions that can cause nipple discharge?
a: Common breast conditions that can cause nipple discharge include breastfeeding or pregnancy, a blocked or enlarged milk duct, a small non-cancerous lump in the breast, a breast infection, or a side effect of a medicine.
